official-title.#text:
To ensure high standards for Federal agency use of
		  scientific information.

committee-name.#text:
Committee
			 on Oversight and Government Reform

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Ensuring high
			 standards for agency use of scientific information

text.#text:
Not later than January 1, 2014, each Federal
			 agency shall have in effect guidelines for ensuring and maximizing the quality,
			 objectivity, utility, and integrity of scientific information relied upon by
			 such agency.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, with
			 respect to a Federal agency, shall ensure that—

text.#text:
when scientific
			 information is considered by the agency in policy decisions—

the agency
			 appropriately applies the scientific information to the policy decision;

except for
			 information that is protected from disclosure by law or administrative
			 practice, the agency makes available to the public the scientific information
			 considered by the agency;

the agency gives
			 greatest weight to information that is based on experimental, empirical,
			 quantifiable, and reproducible data that is developed in accordance with
			 well-established scientific processes; and

with respect to
			 any proposed rule issued by the agency, such agency follows procedures that
			 include, to the extent feasible and permitted by law, an opportunity for public
			 comment on all relevant scientific findings;

the agency has
			 procedures in place to make policy decisions only on the basis of the best
			 reasonably obtainable scientific, technical, economic, and other evidence and
			 information concerning the need for, consequences of, and alternatives to the
			 decision; and

the agency has in
			 place procedures to identify and address instances in which the integrity of
			 scientific information considered by the agency may have been compromised,
			 including instances in which such information may have been the product of a
			 scientific process that was compromised.
